ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Peer tutor and office hours
Textbook
Recorded review sessions
Some videos as part of the "explorations."
office hours.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course covered Calc 2 concepts including integration, series, volumes, parametric equations, and polar coordinates. I took my high school's Calc 2 class but I didn't feel comfortable with some of the material. I feel more comfortable with the material after having taken Math 115.
A more thorough and deep understanding of calculus
Organization and learning to study properly, as well as calculus of course.
Covered principles of calculus including Riemann sums, integration strategies, convergence tests, Taylor series, parametric equations, and polar functions.
Exactly what you'd expect! A normal, well-taught calculus II class.
How to do calculus at a higher level.
I learned calculus II

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The course is poorly organized. Different instructors teach different sections and the quality of instruction varies quite a bit.
The simplest thing that could be done to improve this course would be to put links to ALL instructors' office hours on the umbrella canvas site so that students could easily go to other instructors' office hours for a different explanation or just due to scheduling conflicts.

The peer tutors for the course were helpful.
Well structured, however more supplementary course materials would be helpful
You feel very detached from p-sets after handing them in, I never saw what I got right and wrong on them. It would be helpful to have a more robust mechanism around looking at your pset grades.

I think the structure of the course (lecture, explorations, problem sets, concept checks) was a strength because it made every gave me enough practice with problems to be prepared for exams. I think that concept checks would be completed more if they were mandatory.

Strength: You learn what you need to know. Weakness: Sort of boring, but I understand that the material is very standard for any calc II course, and it is taught well and efficiently so I guess it's fine haha.
The questions in the class and psets seemed much easier than those in the exams. I did not have any issue with my TA and thought he did a good job teaching.
It was a little hard to follow along and easy to tune out.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I didn't find the live virtual lectures engaging. I liked the "explorations" so that I could preview the material before class.
online medium didn't have any major issues
Instructor's handwriting was really bad and lectures were sometimes less helpful than I wanted them to be. The breakout rooms were awful.
I think it succeeded despite the pandemic, the online sessions worked very well for this format. It was harder to work with classmates on things, but that wasn't that big of a deal.

I think that the virtual lectures were good, but an hour and 15 minutes, especially in the afternoon is a long time to go without a break. I found it extremely difficult to keep the same level of focus towards the end of the lecture, and I would have appreciated a mandated 3 minute break in the middle of the lecture to allow students to stretch and stop staring at their screens for a second in between the 40-45 minute mark.
I thought the course was well adapted to online learning.
nothing.
I liked the breakout rooms but disliked the atmosphere.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Only if you need to take it for a QR credit or for your major. Try to get a section with Brett Smith as he does the best job explaining the material and has really helpful office hours. Workload-wise, this course is fine.
If you need to take a calculus class, this is the course for you.
Yes. While I did not feel like I built a connection with any of the other students or teachers, I learned a lot of math.
Yea, but only to fill a requirement. Pretty boring. Take instead of 120 if you are premed.
No. Unless you are a math or physics major, other math classes seem like they would be more helpful in other disciplines.
Yes, because I think calculus is valuable, not because I enjoyed it.
